categories.biometrics: Personal characteristics that inform training recommendations

terms.description: One complete lift and lower of an exercise. Do 10 reps means doing the movement 10 times.
A group of reps done without stopping. 3 sets of 10 means doing 10 reps, resting, then repeating twice more.
The heaviest weight you can lift once with good form. Used to calculate training weights (like 80% of 1RM).
How heavy or hard the exercise is. Usually measured as weight lifted or percentage of your max.
Total work done, calculated as sets × reps × weight. More volume generally means more muscle growth.
terms.details: General guidelines per muscle group per week: Maintenance requires 3-6 sets (6-10 for adults 60+). Growth requires 10-20 sets. Limit each session to ~10-11 sets per muscle. Distribute volume across 1-2 sessions per week (2-3 for adults 60+).

references.author: Schoenfeld et al.
references.title: Dose-response relationship between weekly resistance training volume and increases in muscle mass

terms.description: How often you train. Can refer to workouts per week or how many times you hit each muscle per week.
How far a joint can move. Full range of motion means going through the entire movement, like a squat all the way down and up.
The speed of each rep. A 3/0/2/1 tempo means 3 seconds down, no pause, 2 seconds up, 1 second at top.
A lighter set done before your main work to prepare muscles and joints. Usually about half the weight for 12-15 reps.
A set done at your target weight - the sets that count toward your training, not warm-ups.
An exercise using multiple joints at once. Squats, deadlifts, and bench press are compound movements.
An exercise using only one joint. Biceps curls, leg extensions, and lateral raises are isolation movements.
A main lift that works muscles with heavy loads. Usually compound movements like squat, bench, row, and press.
A supporting exercise done after main lifts. Targets specific muscles the basic exercises may under-emphasize.
An exercise where your hands or feet stay fixed. Squats, push-ups, and pull-ups are closed-chain because you push against a fixed surface.
An exercise where your hands or feet move freely through space. Leg extensions and biceps curls are open-chain.
The lifting phase where the muscle shortens. Curling the weight up in a biceps curl is concentric.
The lowering phase where the muscle lengthens under load. Lowering the weight in a biceps curl is eccentric.
Holding a position without moving. A plank or pausing mid-rep is isometric - the muscle works but doesn't change length.
The main muscle driving a movement. During a biceps curl, the biceps is the agonist.
The muscle opposite the working muscle. During a biceps curl, the triceps is the antagonist and must relax to allow the movement.
A helper muscle that assists the main muscle. During a biceps curl, the brachialis helps the biceps bend the elbow.
A muscle that holds a joint steady without moving. Your core stabilizes your spine during a squat.
A two-joint muscle that stays roughly the same length during movement by shortening at one joint while lengthening at another.
Bending a joint to decrease the angle. Bending your elbow or bringing your thigh toward your chest is flexion.
Straightening a joint to increase the angle. Straightening your arm or kicking your leg back is extension.
Rotating your forearm so the palm faces down, like pouring out water.
Rotating your forearm so the palm faces up, like holding a bowl of soup.
Moving a limb away from your body's centerline. Raising your arm to the side is shoulder abduction.
Moving a limb toward your body's centerline. Lowering your arm back to your side is shoulder adduction.
Muscle growth from training. Your existing muscle fibers get bigger rather than multiplying.
Muscle shrinkage from not using it. Happens during inactivity, injury, or aging.
Muscle soreness appearing 1-2 days after a workout. Caused by tiny muscle fiber tears, especially from new exercises or heavy lowering (eccentric) work.
Gradually making workouts harder over time by adding weight, reps, or sets. The key driver of long-term progress.
An easy-to-learn exercise with simple technique. Machine exercises and basic bodyweight movements are beginner-friendly.
terms.details: Examples include push-ups, goblet squats, and machine-based exercises. These movements allow trainees to focus on developing basic motor patterns and building foundational strength without excessive injury risk.

terms.description: An exercise requiring some practice. Free weight barbell and dumbbell exercises need more skill than machines.
terms.details: Examples include barbell squats, dumbbell rows, and lunges. These movements build on foundational patterns and introduce greater stability challenges and loading potential.

terms.description: A challenging exercise requiring significant strength or skill. Pistol squats and Olympic lifts take years to master.
terms.details: Examples include pistol squats, handstand push-ups, and Olympic lifts. These movements require substantial training experience and should only be attempted after mastering foundational and intermediate progressions.

terms.description: When you can't complete another rep with good form. Training to failure means pushing until this point.
Two exercises done back-to-back with no rest between them. Often pairs opposite muscles like chest and back.
Reducing the weight after hitting failure and immediately continuing for more reps. Extends the set beyond normal failure.
Extra reps done with help from a spotter after you can't complete any more on your own.
Doing an isolation exercise before a compound movement for the same muscle. Like chest flies before bench press.
How long your muscle works during a set. Slower reps or more reps increase time under tension.
A 1-10 scale for how hard a set feels. RPE 7 means you could do 3 more reps; RPE 10 means you had nothing left.
Pushing weight away from you. Bench press, overhead press, and push-ups are push exercises.
Pulling weight toward you. Rows, pull-ups, and curls are pull exercises.
Bending forward at the hips while keeping your back flat. Deadlifts, Romanian deadlifts, and good mornings use this pattern.
Sitting down and standing up - bending at the hips, knees, and ankles together while keeping your torso upright.
How the difficulty changes through a lift's range of motion. Some exercises get harder at the top, bottom, or middle.
Pushing your feet into the floor during bench press to create full-body tension and stability.
The end position where joints are fully straightened. The top of a squat or bench press.
The hardest part of a lift where most people fail. On bench press, it's usually a few inches off the chest.
Someone who watches your lift and helps if you get stuck. Essential for heavy bench press and squats.
How you position and move your body during an exercise. Good form maximizes results and prevents injury.
The main muscle an exercise works. Bench press targets the chest.
Where a muscle attaches closer to your torso. This end stays relatively still during movement.
Where a muscle attaches farther from your torso. This end moves toward the origin when the muscle contracts.
A muscle crossing two joints. Hamstrings cross the hip and knee, so leg position affects how much they stretch.
When a two-joint muscle can't shorten enough to fully move both joints at once. Example: hamstrings can't fully extend the hip and flex the knee simultaneously.
When a two-joint muscle can't stretch enough to allow full movement at both joints at once. Example: tight hamstrings limit hip flexion when the knee is straight.
Normal weight training where you move through a range of motion. Includes both lifting and lowering phases.
Movement at constant speed using specialized machines. The machine adjusts resistance to match your force throughout the rep.
Imaginary vertical slice dividing the body into left and right halves. Forward/backward movements like squats happen in this plane.
Imaginary vertical slice dividing the body into front and back halves. Side-to-side movements like lateral raises happen in this plane.
Imaginary horizontal slice dividing the body into upper and lower halves. Rotational movements like twisting happen in this plane.
Toward the front of the body. Your chest is anterior to your spine.
Toward the back of the body. Your shoulder blades are posterior to your chest.
Toward the center of the body. Your inner thigh is medial to your outer thigh.
Away from the center of the body. Your outer thigh is lateral to your inner thigh.
Closer to the torso. Your shoulder is proximal to your elbow.
Farther from the torso. Your hand is distal to your elbow.
Toward the head. Your shoulders are superior to your hips.
Away from the head. Your hips are inferior to your shoulders.
Rotating a limb inward toward your body's center. Turning your arm so your thumb points toward your body.
Rotating a limb outward away from your body's center. Turning your arm so your thumb points away from your body.
Moving a limb in a circle. Your arm drawing circles in the air is circumduction.
Pulling your toes up toward your shin.
Pointing your toes down away from your shin. The motion of going up on your tiptoes.
Tilting the sole of your foot inward so it faces the other foot.
Tilting the sole of your foot outward away from the other foot.
Rotational force around a joint. Longer limbs create more torque, making the same weight feel heavier at certain positions.
A bone rotating around a joint. Your body uses lever systems to multiply force or speed depending on muscle attachment points.
The angle at which a muscle pulls on a bone. Muscles generate the most rotational force when pulling at 90 degrees to the bone.
Exercise gets easier as you complete the rep. Squats and bench press are hardest at the bottom and easiest at lockout.
Exercise gets harder as you complete the rep. Rows and chin-ups are easiest at the bottom and hardest at the top.
Exercise is hardest in the middle of the rep. Biceps curls are toughest when your elbow is bent at 90 degrees.
Using both sides at once. Barbell squats and bench press are bilateral - both legs or arms work together.
Using one side at a time. Single-leg squats and one-arm rows are unilateral - each limb works independently.
You can lift more total weight doing single-leg or single-arm exercises than both limbs together. A normal neurological effect.
Where bones meet to form a joint. Different joints allow different movements - knees hinge, shoulders rotate.
Objects resist changes in motion. Heavier weights are harder to start moving and harder to stop once moving.
Force equals mass times acceleration. Moving heavier weights or moving faster both require more force from your muscles.
Every force has an equal opposite force. Push hard into the floor during a squat and the floor pushes back, driving you up.
Energy from food. Eating enough supports muscle building and performance; eating too little hurts recovery and hormones.
terms.details: Low energy availability (LEA) occurs when caloric intake fails to meet the demands of exercise and bodily functions. Meta-analyses show LEA affects 45% of athletes and is linked to decreased endurance, coordination, and increased injury risk.

references.author: Statuta et al.
references.title: Low energy availability and relative energy deficiency in sport: a systematic review and meta-analysis

terms.description: The building block for muscle. Aim for 1.6-2.2 grams per kilogram of body weight daily when training.
terms.details: Meta-analyses of 49 studies show protein supplementation augments resistance training gains in muscle mass and strength. Benefits plateau at ~1.6 g/kg/day total intake, with older adults potentially benefiting from 1.2-1.6 g/kg/day.

references.author: Morton et al.
references.title: A systematic review, meta-analysis and meta-regression of the effect of protein supplementation on resistance training-induced gains in muscle mass and strength in healthy adults

terms.description: Plant material your body can't digest. Supports gut health and is linked to lower disease risk. Found in vegetables, fruits, and whole grains.
terms.details: An umbrella review of 17 million individuals found convincing evidence linking fibre intake to reduced CVD mortality, pancreatic cancer, and diverticular disease. Benefits appear dose-dependent with no upper threshold identified.

references.author: Veronese et al.
references.title: Dietary fibre and health outcomes: an umbrella review of systematic reviews and meta-analyses

terms.description: Staying hydrated supports performance. Losing just 2% of body weight in sweat hurts endurance, especially in heat.
terms.details: Systematic reviews show fluid intake following dehydration improves continuous exercise performance, particularly at elevated temperatures. Pre-exercise hyperhydration may help delay adverse effects of fluid loss during prolonged exercise.

references.author: McCartney et al.
references.title: The effect of fluid intake following dehydration on subsequent athletic and cognitive performance: a systematic review and meta-analysis

terms.description: Daily walking activity. More steps generally means better health, with benefits peaking around 8,000-10,000 steps per day.
terms.details: A meta-analysis of 47,471 adults found that compared to the lowest step group (~3,500 steps/day), those averaging 10,900 steps had 40-53% lower mortality risk. Benefits plateau around 6,000-8,000 steps for adults over 60, and 8,000-10,000 for younger adults.

references.author: Paluch et al.
references.title: Daily steps and all-cause mortality: a meta-analysis of 15 international cohorts

terms.description: Rest essential for recovery and muscle growth. Most people need 7-9 hours; getting more can improve athletic performance.
terms.details: Systematic reviews show sleep extension improves reaction time, sprint performance, and shooting accuracy in athletes. Collegiate basketball players extending sleep to 10 hours showed 9% improved free-throw accuracy and faster sprint times.

references.author: Cunha et al.
references.title: The impact of sleep interventions on athletic performance: a systematic review

terms.description: A 1-10 self-rating of how ready you feel to train. Low scores suggest you need more rest before your next hard workout.
terms.details: The Perceived Recovery Status (PRS) scale correlates with markers of muscle damage and performance decrements. Research shows it can effectively assess daily recovery following resistance exercise, though the relationship is individualized.

references.author: Sikorski et al.
references.title: Changes in perceived recovery status scale following high-volume muscle damaging resistance exercise

terms.description: How many more reps you could have done. RIR 2 means you stopped with 2 reps left in the tank.
terms.details: RIR provides a practical way to auto-regulate training intensity. Research suggests training within 0-3 RIR optimizes hypertrophy while managing fatigue. Higher RIR (4+) may be appropriate for technique practice or deload periods.

terms.description: The minimum sets per muscle per week to keep what you have. About 6 sets per muscle maintains size during busy periods.
terms.details: Research shows young adults can maintain muscle with as few as 3 sets per muscle per week if intensity is preserved. Adults over 60 typically require 6-10 sets per week. Maintaining load (intensity) is more critical than maintaining volume.

references.author: Bickel et al.
references.title: Exercise dosing to retain resistance training adaptations in young and older adults

references.author: Spiering et al.
references.title: Maintaining physical performance: the minimal dose of exercise needed to preserve endurance and strength over time

terms.description: The minimum sets per muscle per week to grow. Around 8-10 sets per muscle is where growth begins for most people.
terms.details: MEV varies by training status and muscle group. Beginners may see growth with fewer sets, while advanced trainees require more. Starting a training block at MEV allows room to progressively increase volume.

references.author: Schoenfeld et al.
references.title: Dose-response relationship between weekly resistance training volume and increases in muscle mass: a systematic review and meta-analysis

terms.description: The sweet spot for muscle growth. Around 12-18 sets per muscle per week provides the best returns for most people.
terms.details: MAV represents the progression zone between MEV and MRV. Each session increases fatigue, requiring progressive volume increases to maintain optimal stimulus. The ideal volume varies by individual recovery capacity and training experience.

references.author: Schoenfeld et al.
references.title: Dose-response relationship between weekly resistance training volume and increases in muscle mass: a systematic review and meta-analysis

references.author: Pelland et al.
references.title: The resistance training dose response: meta-regressions exploring the effects of weekly volume and frequency on muscle hypertrophy and strength gains

terms.description: The most you can do and still recover. Going beyond 20-25 sets per muscle per week leads to burnout, not more growth.
terms.details: Training at MRV is unsustainable long-term and leads to overtraining symptoms. Research suggests diminishing returns occur well before MRV, with per-session benefits plateauing around 11 sets. Distribute volume across 2-3 sessions for better results.

references.author: Remmert et al.
references.title: Is there too much of a good thing? Meta-regressions of the effect of per-session volume on hypertrophy and strength

references.author: Pelland et al.
references.title: The resistance training dose response: meta-regressions exploring the effects of weekly volume and frequency on muscle hypertrophy and strength gains

terms.description: Affects recovery speed and training needs. Older adults may need more frequent sessions with more recovery time between them.
terms.details: Adults 60+ show better hypertrophy outcomes when training each muscle 2-3 times per week rather than once. They may need 6-10 sets per muscle weekly for maintenance (vs 3-6 for younger adults) and benefit from longer rest periods. Age-related declines in muscle protein synthesis can be offset by adequate protein intake (1.2-1.6 g/kg/day) and progressive resistance training.

references.author: Bickel et al.
references.title: Exercise dosing to retain resistance training adaptations in young and older adults

references.author: Schoenfeld et al.
references.title: Dose-response relationship between weekly resistance training volume and increases in muscle mass

terms.description: Affects strength baselines, hormones, and how body measurements relate to health. Both sexes benefit equally from resistance training.
terms.details: Males typically have higher absolute strength due to greater muscle mass and testosterone levels, but relative strength gains from training are similar between sexes. Females may recover faster between sets and sessions, potentially tolerating higher training frequencies. Sex also affects how body measurements predict health risk: males tend to accumulate visceral fat centrally while females store more subcutaneously, making waist circumference thresholds sex-specific (94 cm risk threshold for males vs 80 cm for females). Body fat percentage norms differ substantially (essential fat ~3% for males vs ~12% for females). Both sexes benefit equally from resistance training for health outcomes.

references.author: Roberts et al.
references.title: Sex differences in resistance training: a systematic review and meta-analysis

references.author: Ashwell et al.
references.title: Waist-to-height ratio is a better screening tool than waist circumference and BMI for adult cardiometabolic risk factors

terms.description: Affects exercise mechanics and leverage. Also used to calculate waist-to-height ratio, a useful health indicator.
terms.details: For exercise: longer limbs create longer moment arms, requiring more work through the same angular range. Taller lifters often benefit from wider stances and adjusted grip widths. For health assessment: waist-to-height ratio (WHtR) is a stronger predictor of cardiometabolic risk than BMI or waist circumference alone. A WHtR below 0.5 indicates lower risk regardless of sex or ethnicity, while values above 0.6 indicate substantially elevated risk. This ratio normalizes waist measurement across different body sizes, making it more universally applicable than fixed waist thresholds.

references.author: Ashwell et al.
references.title: Waist-to-height ratio is a better screening tool than waist circumference and BMI for adult cardiometabolic risk factors

terms.description: Your body mass in kilograms or pounds. Daily fluctuations are normal; track weekly averages for reliable trends.
terms.details: Daily weight fluctuates 1-2 kg due to hydration, food intake, and glycogen levels. Weekly averages provide more reliable trend data than single measurements. For body composition goals, the rate of weight change matters: muscle gain typically occurs at 0.25-0.5 kg/month for trained individuals, while fat loss of 0.5-1% bodyweight per week preserves muscle mass.

references.author: Helms et al.
references.title: Evidence-based recommendations for natural bodybuilding contest preparation: nutrition and supplementation

terms.description: Your heart rate at rest, normally 60-100 bpm. Lower is usually better. Elevated readings can signal stress or incomplete recovery.
terms.details: Endurance training can reduce resting heart rate by 10-20 bpm over months. Elevated resting heart rate may indicate incomplete recovery, stress, or illness. Measure first thing in the morning before rising for consistent readings. Values below 60 bpm are common in trained athletes and generally not concerning without symptoms.

references.author: Reimers et al.
references.title: Effects of exercise on the resting heart rate: a systematic review and meta-analysis
